narrative: The expiration date on the pen itself is missing. The space where it's supposed to be printed is just a blank white box. The outer carton has a date, but I need to be able to verify it on the actual device for safety.
reasoning: Missing critical labeling information on the device.

narrative: There's a bunch of tiny white flakes at the bottom of the pen. They look like dandruff or little crystals. I tried shaking it gently to see if they would dissolve, but they just float around and then settle back down. It's definitely not a clear solution anymore.
The delivery truck had no AC. The box was scorching hot. The medication is cooked. It needs to be refrigerated.
My pen broke in half when I took the cap off. The plastic snapped right at the threads. The cartridge fell out and smashed on the floor. The plastic felt very brittle.

I pushed the button to inject but no liquid came out. The counter went down to 0, but I didn't feel the injection and there was no drop on the needle tip. I checked the flow and nothing is coming out. It's clogged.
reasoning: Failure to deliver dose despite counter movement.

narrative: There is a grey particle in the solution. It looks like metal dust. It settles to the bottom. I'm returning it.
The pen looks fake. The blue is the wrong shade. The plastic feels cheap. The label is crooked. It's a not authentic.

I received my Ozempic shipment from the mail order pharmacy and when I opened the insulated shipping container, I was hit with this strong chemical smell that definitely shouldn't be there. It smelled kind of like rubbing alcohol or disinfectant, really pungent and unpleasant. The smell was coming from inside the package, not from the outside box. When I examined the pens themselves through their sealed packaging, the cartons and pens looked normal, but that chemical odor was concerning. I'm worried that maybe the pens were exposed to some kind of cleaning chemical during storage or shipping, or that there was a spill of some kind in the warehouse that contaminated the packaging. Even though the medication is sealed inside the pen cartridge, I don't feel comfortable using product that was shipped in packaging that has such a strong chemical smell. What if whatever chemical caused that smell somehow penetrated the packaging or contaminated the exterior surfaces? I'd be handling those surfaces when preparing my injection. Called the mail order pharmacy customer service and after describing the smell, they agreed to send a replacement shipment and have me return the odorous one. They said they'd investigate whether there was a contamination incident in their distribution center. Better safe than sorry with something like this.
reasoning: Strong chemical odor from packaging suggests potential contamination during storage or shipping.

narrative: I accidentally left the box of pens on the kitchen counter for 24 hours in a warm room before I realized they should have gone in the fridge. I know they're supposed to stay cold until they're first used.
reasoning: Patient error resulting in room-temp exposure.

narrative: There's a small piece of dark material floating in the pen that looks like a fragment of wood or cardboard. I don't know how it got in there, but it's definitely not part of the medication. I'm returning it to the pharmacy.
There is a speck of dirt inside the glass cartridge. It's dark and grainy. It's definitely inside the liquid. That's not sterile.
The pen leaked the whole dose onto my leg. The needle was on tight. It leaked from the pen body seams.

Medication is leaking out from the side of the pen body, not the needle, whenever I apply pressure. There must be a crack in the internal housing or a failed seal somewhere inside. It's getting all over my hands instead of going into my skin.
The dial made a loud cracking sound when I was turning it, and now it just spins freely without changing the dose numbers. I can't set my 0.5 mg dose because the internal gears must have snapped.
reasoning: Mechanical breakage of the dial mechanism.

narrative: My blood sugar usually drops within 24 hours of my shot, but this time it's stayed consistently high. I even checked the pen to make sure I actually injected, and the dose counter moved, but I'm just not feeling any of the usual effects. This batch feels very weak.
The lot number is missing from the carton. The space is blank. I can't check if it's recalled. The pharmacy said it's a printing error from the manufacturer.
There is oil separation in the liquid. It looks like salad dressing that needs shaking. It's supposed to be a uniform solution. Something is wrong with the formulation.

I opened the box and the pen was sitting in a pool of liquid. The cap was wet and when I took it off, I could see fluid leaking from the cartridge. It smells like insulin or medicine. I haven't used it but half the liquid is gone. I think the cartridge is cracked.

I'm reporting what I believe to be diverted or possibly not authentic Ozempic that I unfortunately purchased. I was looking for better prices and found an online seller advertising bulk discounts - offering twelve pens at a significant savings if you bought in quantity. They claimed to ship from Canada to the US, which I thought was legal for personal use. Placed an order and the pens arrived a few weeks later. As soon as I opened the package, I knew something was off. All the labeling is in French only, no English at all. The box design looks similar to Ozempic packaging but the colors and layout are slightly different from what I'm used to. The color scheme doesn't match the FDA-approved packaging I've seen before. I tried looking up the NDC number online and it returns no results in the US database - like the code doesn't exist in our system. My regular pharmacist looked at it and immediately said this is likely diverted product from the Canadian market that's not approved for sale in the US. Different packaging, different regulatory approval, possibly different manufacturing standards or quality oversight. Or it could be not authentic made to look like Canadian product. Either way, she strongly advised not to use it and to report the seller. The medication came from an unauthorized distribution channel and doesn't meet US regulatory requirements. I'm out the money and learned a hard lesson about buying prescription drugs from random online sellers offering bulk discounts.
reasoning: Foreign-labeled product with unapproved packaging from unauthorized channel indicates diversion or counterfeit.

narrative: The ice packs in my mail-order shipment were actually still frozen solid, but they were placed directly against the pens without any padding. The liquid in the pens was frozen into a slushy ice. I know you're not supposed to freeze this stuff, so I'm assuming it's ruined.

The instructions for use inside the box are for a completely different medication—something called Victoza. The box and the pen say Ozempic, but the booklet is wrong. If I followed these instructions, I might have used the device incorrectly.
The text on the pen is blurry. I can't read the dose window markings. The printing is bad quality.
There is a piece of metal wire inside the cartridge. It looks like a staple. It's rusting in the liquid. This is dangerous contamination.
The shrink wrap was missing from the carton. Anyone could have opened it. I don't feel safe using medication that isn't sealed properly.

The pen I received from the pharmacy today has an expiration date that passed six months ago. I can't believe they didn't catch this before handing it over to me. It's a huge oversight by the distribution team.

Something is definitely wrong with this pen and I'm concerned the medication might be diluted or has incorrect concentration. Yesterday was my injection day, so I dialed up my usual 0.5 mg dose on the pen and did the injection. But it felt different than normal - the injection was over really quickly, much faster than usual, and it felt too easy, like there wasn't the usual resistance. At first I thought maybe I just imagined it, but then over the next 24 hours I didn't feel any of the usual effects of the medication. No appetite suppression, no GI effects, nothing. Like I hadn't taken anything at all. So I ended up dialing another 0.5 mg dose and taking it again, and same thing - too quick, too easy, no effect. By the end of the day I had dialed and injected the 0.5 mg dose three times total, thinking maybe it wasn't delivering properly or I was doing something wrong. But I'm experienced with this medication, I know how it should feel and work. My concern is that this particular pen might have diluted medication or incorrect concentration. Like maybe the active ingredient amount is lower than it should be. Otherwise why would I feel absolutely nothing after three doses when one dose normally has a clear effect? I kept the pen and brought it to the pharmacy. They're sending it to the manufacturer for potency testing because if the concentration is wrong in this lot, that's a serious quality control and safety issue affecting dosing accuracy.
reasoning: Apparent lack of expected pharmacological effect combined with unusual delivery suggests potency issue.

narrative: My shipment sat in a delivery truck for two days during a heatwave where temps reached over 100 degrees. When I opened the package, the ice packs were not just melted, they were actually warm to the touch. The medication box felt like it had been in an oven.

The National Drug Code (NDC) on the pen doesn't match the one on the box. They are close, but the last few digits are different. This makes me worry that the wrong medication or the wrong strength was put in this box.
This pen seems to have just water in it. It's clear but it has no effect. My glucose is 300. It's useless.
The foil seal on the pen cap was open. It's not sterile. I can't use it. It was like that in the box.
The box was soaked in water when it arrived. The cardboard is falling apart. The pens inside are wet. I don't know if the water was clean or dirty. The integrity is compromised.

I'm a new patient just starting on Ozempic and when I got home with my prescription and opened the carton to read through everything before my first dose, I realized the patient information leaflet is completely missing. You know, that folded paper insert that's supposed to have all the instructions for use and important safety information? It's just not in the box at all. The carton had the pen and the needle tips but no paperwork whatsoever. This is my first time using this medication so I really needed those instructions. I drove back to the pharmacy and explained the situation to the pharmacist, and she was nice enough to photocopy the instruction leaflet from another box they had in stock so at least I'd have something to reference. But she said she's never seen one come without the insert before and that it should always be included. She filed a complaint or whatever they call it about the missing component. It makes me wonder what else might be wrong with that batch if they're missing basic packaging components like that. How many other people got boxes without instructions and maybe just tried to figure it out on their own without the proper safety information?
reasoning: Missing IFU insert is a packaging component defect affecting safe use.

narrative: The liquid has separated into layers. Oil and water. It shouldn't look like that. It's spoiled.

I found a really concerning labeling discrepancy that makes me question which batch of medication I actually have. I was documenting my medication information for my records like I always do, and I noticed that the batch number printed on the actual pen body says batch U8537B. But when I looked at the batch number printed on the outer carton, it says T8537B. The first character is different - U on the pen, T on the carton. Everything else in the batch code is the same, and the expiry dates match between the pen and carton, but that first character difference is significant. Batch numbers are supposed to be unique identifiers for traceability purposes. If there's a recall or quality issue, you need to be able to identify exactly which batch a product came from. With the pen and carton showing different batch codes, there's no way to accurately trace this product. Is the pen from batch U or batch T? I called the pharmacy to ask about this discrepancy and the pharmacist couldn't explain it. She said it shouldn't happen and they're documenting it. I returned the pen because without accurate batch identification, I can't be confident about the product's provenance, quality testing, or whether it's even the right medication. This seems like a label mismatch or mix-up during packaging where pens from one batch got put in cartons labeled for a different batch.
reasoning: Batch number discrepancy between device and carton prevents accurate traceability.

narrative: When I try to press the injection button, it feels like there's something blocking it internally. It takes an incredible amount of force to get it to budge, and even then, it only moves a tiny bit before getting stuck again. I'm afraid I'm not getting the full dose because the mechanism just isn't advancing the plunger correctly.
reasoning: Mechanical resistance in the injection button.

narrative: The QR code takes me to a fake website. It asks for my credit card. This product is a scam.
The pen feels very light, like it's empty. I can see liquid but maybe it's not full. I weighed it compared to my old one and it's lighter. I think it's underfilled.
This medication is 2 years past expiration. I found it in the back of my grandma's fridge. Can I still use it?

The pharmacy is trying to sell me pens that expire in 10 days. I need a supply that lasts for at least a month. They told me 'it's all they have', but I'm not paying for medicine that will be officially past its date halfway through my treatment.
reasoning: Supply of medication with inadequate remaining shelf life.

narrative: I made a careless mistake and I'm really upset with myself. I travel for work and I keep my Ozempic in a small insulated travel case so I can take it with me. Last week I was rushing to catch a flight and I put the case in my car trunk instead of bringing it into the house. Then I completely forgot about it. This happened to be during a cold snap we had, with overnight temperatures dropping down to around 20 degrees Fahrenheit. The pens were in my car trunk for three full days in subfreezing temperatures before I remembered and went to retrieve them. When I opened the case and looked at the pens, I could see that the solution was partially frozen - there were visible ice crystals inside the cartridge when I held it up to the window. I brought them inside and let them thaw completely at room temperature. Once thawed, the solution looks clear again and the ice crystals are gone, but I know from the storage instructions that Ozempic should never be frozen. Even if it looks normal after thawing, freezing can denature the protein and make the medication ineffective or unreliable. I called my doctor's office and the nurse confirmed I need to throw these pens away and get new ones. Can't use medication that's been frozen even though it looks okay now. So I'm out two pens because of my own mistake. Just documenting this in case anyone else accidentally freezes their medication - don't try to use it even after it thaws.
reasoning: Freezing exposure violates storage conditions and likely denatures the protein therapeutic.

narrative: The dose dial is stuck between numbers. It won't click into place. I can't select the correct dose.

I checked the lot number on the manufacturer's website to verify the authenticity, and the system says that lot number doesn't exist. I'm really concerned because I've already used one of the pens from this box. This looks like a not authentic batch.
I suspect these pens are not authentic. The packaging looks low quality and the colors are off. The QR code on the side doesn't scan. The price was too good to be true.
reasoning: Visual discrepancies and scan failure indicating counterfeit.

narrative: I was getting ready to take my very first dose of Ozempic today, so I followed the instructions exactly like it says in the booklet. I attached the needle, did the priming procedure, turned the dial to release the air and prime it, heard the clicking sound like it's supposed to make, but then nothing. No drop appeared at the needle tip at all. So I thought maybe it was the needle, took it off, put on a brand new one from the pack, tried again. Same thing. Clicked, but no medication came out. I probably tried this about five or six times with two different needles and I'm getting nowhere. The mechanism inside seems to be working - I can hear the clicks, the dial turns, but it's like the medication just won't flow through. Something must be blocked inside the pen. I called the pharmacy and they said this shouldn't happen and to bring it back for a replacement. Really frustrating because I was supposed to start my treatment today and now I have to wait.
reasoning: Failure to prime/deliver dose suggests internal blockage or mechanism failure in the prefilled pen.

narrative: I pressed the button to inject, but the plunger didn't move at all. The counter stayed at 0.5 mg. I tried again, pressing much harder, and still nothing. The device is completely unresponsive even though I followed the priming steps.

I screwed the needle on and tried to prime the pen like the manual says, but nothing comes out of the needle. I tried a second needle, but still no drop appears at the tip. It seems like the internal channel of the pen is blocked or not engaging with the needle.

There are multiple issues with the packaging integrity of the pen I just received that make me question whether it's safe to use. First, the transparent plastic shrink wrap or cellophane wrapper that's supposed to be tightly sealed around the outer carton was really loose and baggy. I was able to easily slide it off without tearing anything or breaking any seal - it just slipped right off. That wrapper is supposed to be tamper-evident, so if it comes off that easily, how do I know someone hasn't already opened it? Then I opened the carton and looked at the internal blister seal - you know, that foil or plastic seal that covers the pen inside the tray. That seal was partially open at one corner. Like it had been peeled back or never fully sealed in the first place. You could actually see the edge of the pen through the gap in the seal. Between the loose outer wrapper and the compromised inner seal, the product integrity is really questionable. There's no way to be certain that this pen hasn't been tampered with, contaminated, or exposed to conditions it shouldn't have been. This is an injectable medication - sterility and integrity are absolutely critical. I took it back to the pharmacy immediately and they agreed the packaging failures are unacceptable. They documented it thoroughly, quarantined all the pens from that same lot, and are reporting it to their quality department. They gave me a replacement from a completely different lot with proper intact seals.
reasoning: Multiple compromised seals indicate packaging integrity failure affecting sterility assurance.

narrative: I can see a tiny silver sliver—it looks like a piece of metal—floating in the liquid inside the pen window. I'm worried it's a piece of the manufacturing equipment that broke off during the filling process.
The solution in this pen is not clear. It has a foggy, hazy appearance. It's supposed to be transparent. I compared it to my last pen and the difference is obvious. I'm returning it.

There's an oily film on the surface of the liquid inside the pen window. It looks like a rainbow sheen, similar to oil on water. It doesn't look like a consistent, clear medication. I'm worried the ingredients have separated.

I can't believe this happened but I need to report it. Picked up my Ozempic refill at the pharmacy on Tuesday, came home, did my injection that evening like I'm supposed to. Everything seemed fine. But then the next day I was looking at the pen and happened to glance at the expiration date printed on the carton, and I realized it says it past its date last month. Like a full month ago. This medication was already past its date when the pharmacy dispensed it to me, and I already took one dose from it before I even noticed. When I called the pharmacy they were very apologetic and said it was a system error - apparently this stock should have been flagged as past its date and pulled from their inventory but somehow it wasn't caught. They immediately pulled all remaining pens from that lot off their shelves and are checking their entire inventory system to see how this happened. They replaced my prescription with current, non-past its date pens at no charge, but I'm still concerned about the dose I already took from past its date medication. I mean, my doctor said it's probably fine, it's not like it becomes toxic or anything, but the effectiveness might be reduced. This is a pretty serious distribution and quality control failure that someone dispensed and I used past its date product. The pharmacy is filing an incident report and their district manager contacted me to apologize.
reasoning: Product was supplied beyond expiry; distribution control failure.
